manner after dehydration and carboniza tion. Synthetic methods such as hydro thermal,[5] thermal combustion,[6] and microwave[7] approach usually follow this method. However, most of the present CDs emit in the visible region from blue to orange range. This property severely limits their application in the biomedical field due to the tissue absorption, high autofluores cence of biomolecules, and potential photo damage.[8,9] The CDs, which have intense emission in the farred and nearinfrared (far red and NIR) region (>600 nm), are attracting increasing attention owing to their superior properties, such as minimum
tissue absorption, deep tissue penetration, low interference from autofluorescence and minimal photodamage of the far red and NIR light to biological sample. And many efforts have been paid on the preparation of farred to NIR CDs and their applications in bioanalysis and biomedicine. Though several excellent reviews have discussed the synthesis of CDs and applications in the area of biology,[10] optoelectronics and photocatalysis,[11–13] there are no review focusing on preparing farred to NIR carbon dots and their biomedical applications. Thus, a survey of recent progress in far red to NIR CDs and their applications is necessary and impor tant. In this review, we first introduced the synthesis strategies for the preparation of farred to NIR CDs, including topdown and bottomup method. At the same time, we also summarized the precursors to synthesis and the fluorescence mechanism of farred to NIR CDs. Second, we outlined the recent progress on the applications of farred to NIR CDs in biosensing, bioim aging, and cancer therapy (Figure 1). In conclusion, we discussed the potential development and challenge of preparation and application of farred to NIR CDs in the future.

sections.heading: 2. Preparation of CDs
sections.text: To produce CDs, besides appropriate synthetic conditions, a careful choice of the starting welldefined precursors is also important, which can afford functional CDs with controlled surface chemistry, tuneable optical properties and microscopic morphology. Multifarious precursors, containing animal deriva tives, vegetables, and some other common reagents have been utilized for the preparation of CDs.[14] Recently, by carefully choosing proper precursors, a number of farred to NIR CDs have been reported,[11] and the reported approaches mainly consist of two categories: topdown treatment and bottomup treatment.

sections.heading: As novel fluorescent nanomaterials, carbon dots (CDs) exhibit excellent photostability, good biocompatibility, and high quantum yield (QY). Their superior properties make them promising candidates for biomedical assays
sections.text:
and therapy. Among them, the red-emission (>600 nm) CDs have attracted increasing attention in the past years due to their little damage to the biological matrix, deep tissue penetration, and minimum autofluorescence background of biosamples. This Review, summarizes the recent progress of far-red to near-infrared (NIR) CDs from the preparation and their biological applications. The challenges in designing far-red and NIR CDs and their further applications in biomedical fields are also discussed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the first fluorescent carbon nanoparticles were synthe sized[1] during the purification of singlewalled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) from arcdischarged soot and named as CDs by Sun et al. in 2006,[2] CDs have attracted increasing interest owing to their unique properties, such as small size, excellent biocom patibility and excellent chemical inertness. Recently, massive efforts have been invested in the development of high efficient CDs and these reported methods mainly consist of two catego ries: topdown treatment and bottomup treatment.[3] The top down approach is realized through exfoliating the small carbon nanoparticles from larger mass carbon materials, such as arch discharge,[1] laser ablation,[2] and chemical oxidation synthesis,[4] etc. The bottomup method involves the preparation of CDs by chemically fusing small molecules or polymers in a stepwise

sections.heading: 2.1. Top-Down Treatment
sections.text:
In the topdown approach, CDs were obtained by cutting large particles into a smaller segments in the nanosize range (<10 nm) with different treatments. These methods involve breaking down larger carbon structures, such as nanodia monds,[15] graphite,[2] carbon nanotubes,[16] carbon soot,[17] activated carbon[18] and carbon fibers[19] through discharge, laser ablation, strong acid oxidation and electrochemical oxi dation. Among the several treatments, nitric acid oxidation is a convenient method which can easily introduce oxygen and nitrogen elements and increase the degree of surface defects. The first CDs was obtained in the purification of SWCNTs from arcdischarged soot, which was oxidized with nitric acid.[1] However, these nanosized carbon particles showed no evident fluorescence emissions. Therefore, an acid oxidative treatment was followed to get fluorescence emissions.
Sun and colleagues reported that once nitric acidtreated carbon particles were passivated with organic or polymeric moieties, surface defects of such passivated CDs are stabilized resulting in strong emissions covering a broad range from the visible region to NIR region.[2] Therewith, by using environ mental pollutant diesel soot as the precursor carbon source, Tripathi et al. procured watersoluble CDs by chemical oxidation using HNO3.[20] After separation from HNO3 by reevapora tion, the watersoluble CDs showed multicolored emissions and extended to the red region. The excitation and emission wavelengths are 460 and 625 nm, respectively. In 2015, Pang’s group reported a series of multicolored CDs which were pre pared from carbon fibers by changing reaction conditions. They demonstrated that the fluorescence of CDs is derived from surfacestate emission and that the higher the surface oxida tion of CDs, the more surface defects present thereby resulting in longer emission wavelength of CDs.[19] Also, the emission
wavelength of CDs was observed to display a redshift with the size of CDs increased. This result indicates that both the sur face oxidation and size of the CDs have effect on the emission wavelength of the CDs.
Moreover, electrochemical oxidation also has been used to prepare CDs. For example, Kang’s group synthesized CDs with fluorescent luminance (FL) emission peaks extending into the NIR wavelength range.[21] By using electrochemical exfoliation of graphite in K2S2O8 solution, Yang’s group synthesized uni form CDs with emission peak in the region of farred to NIR (610 nm).[22]

sections.heading: 2.2. Bottom-Up Treatment
sections.text: Bottomup methods are carried out by chemically fusing small molecules or polymers into CDs of desired size range through dehydration and carbonization in a stepwise manner.[14] To date, multitudinous precursors from natural materials to laboratoryproduced chemicals have been used to prepare CDs through hydrothermal,[6,23–25] and microwave[26] assisted approaches.[14] But, most of the present CDs emit blue or green light, severely limiting their development in the biological field. It is a truism that the definition of proper molecular precursors is a valid approach to obtain presumptive CDs by inheriting inherent morphology and structures. On account of the explo ration and efforts of numerous researchers, various materials have been selected as efficient precursors to synthesis farred and NIR CDs, such as citric acid (CA), phenylenediamine (PD), naphthalene, polythiophene (PT), amino acid, and saccharides among others.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. CA-Based CDs
sections.text:
By carefully selecting proper precursors, CDs with strong emission can be obtained. In the wide range of precursors, citric acid (CA), possessing several carboxyl groups, is one of the most common ingredients to produce CDs via the bottom up method.[27] And numerous CDs synthesized from CA and ammonia have been reported.[28] These researchers proved that CA and specific α, β or α, γ biamines were able to synthesize large ring fused 2pyridone based fluorophores. They believed that different fluorescent compounds were contingent on high reactive CA and other nucleophiles.[27,29] Consequently, altering the reaction conditions or the ratio of CA and different amine group, such as ethanediamine (EDA), formamide, urea, thio urea, and dimethylformamide (DMF), red to NIR CDs can be synthesized.
Originally, researchers carried out numerous studies to syn thesize pure redemission CDs by combining CA with different amines. Hu’s group first reported tuneable CDs across the entire visible spectrum which was produced by facilely altering the ratio of CA, ethylene glycol and EDA.[30] They demonstrated that H3PO4 can impel dehydration reaction and increase O content and hence resulted in the red shift of the strongest FL peak. Otyepka’s group proposed a comparative computational study of CDs models CA and EDA and they revealed that red shift of CDs due to electron doping effect, other than pyri dinic, pyrrolic, or amino centers.[31] In 2015, Rogach’s group reported excitationdependent CDs by using anhydrous CA and N(baminoethyl)gaminopropylmethyldimethoxysilane (AEAPMS).[32] The excitationdependent CDs revealed red emis sion at 620 nm with excited at 540 nm. Two years later, using the same reactants, solidstate CDs with emission peaked at 648 nm were first constructed. These CDs exhibit strong red shift and can overcome the selfquenching in the solid state.[33]
By using CA and formamide as precursors, Lin’s group first proposed a microwaveassisted route (heating at 160 °C for 1 h) for preparing excitationdependent CDs across a wide range from 330 to 600 nm (Figure 2a).[34] They demonstrated that the CDs contained multiple emission centers and CN/CO and other functional groups contributed the longwavelength emissions. By improving the synthesis method, Lin’s group prepared higheffi cient red emissive CDs (RCDs) in 2016.[35] The RCDs exhibited some excellent properties including high QY and pure red emis sion (maximum emission at 640 nm). Importantly, compared with other reagents such as water, ethanol and DMF, formamide exerted a major influence on the favorable realization of RCDs, which were attributed to formamide or its products. They con cluded that surface state/defects of CDs and n→π* transition of π systems possessing CN/CN or CO structure possibly caused the intense red emission. In 2017, Xiong’s group synthesized RCDs with a higher QY by a solvothermal method of heating citric acid formamide solution with the addition of EDA.[36]

The asprepared RCDs showed a high efficient excitationinde pendent emission at 627 nm excited at 561 nm. In 2019, Lin’s group designed improved aminorich RCDs emitting at 640 nm using the precursors of CA and formamide, as well as the addi tional polyethyleneimine (PEI) with more structures of EDA and amino groups. Besides, modified with photosensitizer chlorin e6 (Ce6), the RCDs maintained well intrinsic emission properties and achieved enhance cancer photothermal conversion efficiency of 46% by a reduced irradiation power at 671 nm laser.[37]
Urea, which has one more amino group than formamide, is another usual nitrogen source to prepare CDs with CA in the solution of DMF.[38] In 2016, By changing the reaction time and surface nitriding, Chen et al. prepared the CDs with strong visible absorption and fullcolor emission.[39] Their structural characterizations results displayed that the above photolumi nescence property of CDs attributed to three different emitting states, including sp2 carbon core, CO and CN related surface defects.[40] Using CA and urea as precursors, fullcolor CDs with redshifted emission from 448 nm to 638 nm were prepared by changing the volume ratio of different solvent. Aprotic solvent DMF provides a higher degree of dehydration and carbonization of precursors in solvothermal reaction than water, which results in the formation of differently sized sp2conjugated domains in the prepared CDs, leading to redshift (Figure 2b).[41] Sun’s group further certified a new class of fullcolor emission CDs by adjusting the thermalpyrolysis temperature (140–200 °C) and the ratio of precursors CA/urea to control graphitization and surface function in favor of the redshift of CDs.[42] When the molar ratio of CA/urea exceeded 0.7 at 200 °C, the emission peak shifted to 630 nm. The RCDs possess a higher extent of graphitization and functional groups of COOH than those blue CDs and green CDs from a low ratio of CA/urea. Using urea and CA in formamide solution, Holá et al. presented a new series of fullcolor CDs with wellcontrollable fluorescence at blue, green, yellow, and red.[43] Based on the different surface charge of CDs, these individual fluorescent fractions were successfully separated by column chromatography. The RCDs with emission peaked at 630 nm was separated at last for their most negative charge on the surface, which was attributed to the narrowed band gap
due to the increasing graphitic nitrogen in the CDs structures as shown in Figure 3a. Based on numerous analyses, they con cluded that solvent formamide (other than water or DMF) and graphitic nitrogen (instead of pyrrolic and pyridinic nitrogen) were decisive elements for the red shift of the CDs.
By modifying molecules or polymers on the surface of CDs, Rogach’s group successfully prepared CDs with a NIR absorp tion and NIR emission.[44] These CDs showed an absorption peak at 715 nm in DMSO solution. Besides DMSO, the other aprotic polar solutions like DMF, Nmethyl2pyrrolidone (NMP) and poly (vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) also provide electronacceptor groups, such as SO, CO, which are used to modify the outer layers and the edges of the CDs to promote the optical band gap and electron transitions with NIR excitation (Figure 3b).
CA and thiourea, which is the same as urea, except oxygen is replaced by sulfur, were also selected as precursors to pre pare CDs. This S, Ndoping CDs show red emission at 594 nm under excitation at 560 nm.[45] The CDs have QYs of 29% and 22% in ethanol and water, respectively. Yang’s group reported multicolor Ndoped CDs from blue to red by controlling the fusion and carbonization of CA and diaminonaphthalene (DAN) in an ethanol solution via different reaction times and a suitable amount of H2SO4.[46] This was achieved Due to the crucial precursor of DAN emerging large Ndoped sp2 cluster, the assynthesized CDs, yielding a strong emission, were highly surface passivated and crystallized.
In addition to using CA as a carbon source,[47] tartaric acid can also be employed as carbon sources in the synthesis of RCDs. In Dong’s work, the Fdoping strategy was adopted to synthesize RCDs by using tartaric acid and aromatic F bearing moiety.[48] The maximum emission peak of Fdoped RCDs (600 nm) was much longer than that of undoped CDs, confirming that Fdoping result in a large emission redshift.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. PD-Based CDs
sections.text:
Phenylenediamines containing three isomers including ophe nylenediamine (oPD), mphenylenediamine (mPD), and

pphenylenediamine (pPD) have been adopted as a carbon source for producing oCDs, mCDs, and pCDs.[49] Lin’s group designed a facile approach to prepare three kinds of CDs from mPD, oPD, and pPD, emitting blue, green, and red luminescence centered at 435, 535, and 604 nm, respectively, under a single ultraviolet light excitation (Figure 4a).[50] They concluded that the differences between FL emission of these CDs were responsible for the varia tion in their particle size and nitrogen content.
Subsequently, by using oPD as a precursor, several groups have prepared RCDs. Yang’s group achieved RCDs (centered at 710 nm in a dilute ethanol solution, QY 26.28%) with twophoton fluorescence by a facile highoutput method (Figure 4b).[51] Because they can generate large conjugated sp2domains, oPD and dopamine were selected to prepare NIRCDs. The results proved that carbon core and the sur face state synergistically contributed to the red emission. In Xiong’s work, by using oPD and Lglutamic as precursors, a series of CDs with tuneable emission from 443 to 745 nm are obtained by changing the solvent.[52] As shown in Figure 5a, by controlling the dehydration and carbonization processes, the particle size and the content of graphitic nitrogen in CDs can be modulated.
pPD also has been used as a carbon source to prepare RCDs since 2015.[50] Wang et al. reported a microwaveassisted treatment to fabricate CDs with pure red fluorescence (615 nm) in ethanol/water.[53] Their results indicated that Ndoping was facile and effective for the improvement of the optical proper ties of CDs. Using pPD and formamide as precursors, Xiong’s group reported the CDs with luminescence from blue to red.[54] The fully purified CDs were separated via silica column chro matography and showed excitationindependent luminescence. The QY of the RCDs was ≈24%. They presented a rational FL mechanism that different surface states of the CDs were attributed to the different degrees of oxidation on their sur faces, ultimately deciding the color of CDs fluorescence as shown in Figure 5b. And then, by employing pPD and H3PO4
as precursors, Xiong’s group synthesized pure RCDs.[55] Such welldispersed RCDs with emission at 620 nm and QY over 10% were used for fingerprint detection through the electro static interaction between positively charged RCDs and nega tively charged fingerprint residues of seeat and sebum.
Due to the drug molecules with various heteroatoms (such as N, S, and P), Lin’s group proposed a solvothermal method to prepare colortuneable CDs with Ndoping by using antibiotic drugaminosalicylic acid (ASA) as the precursor.[56] The tun ability of fluorescence (FL) emission and the FL efficiency of the excitationdependent CDs were greatly improved with the doping of N element.
Using pPD or the compound containing the structure of pPD as precursors, RCDs were prepared. Chen’s group procured B, N, Scodoped CDs by a onestep hydrothermal treatment with 2, 5diaminobenzenesulfonic acid (contains the structure of pPD) and 4aminophenylboronic acid hydrochloride as precursors.[57] The ratio of B/S influenced the intensity and emission wave length of CDs. In general, doping N, B, and S atoms may be the possible cause of the red emission of CDs and enrich surface functional groups to broaden its application as well.
Using oPD/ pPD as precursors and DMF as the solvent, Xiang’s group designed a facile strategy to produce longwave length emitting OCDs (orange emission with QY of 58.8%)/ pCDs (red emission with QY of 52.4%) without any separation pro cess.[58] The obtained corresponding OCDs/ PCDs exhibit concentrationdependent FL property as well as the “solva tochromism” phenomenon. As the increase in their concentration in solution or in the polarity of solvent, OCDs and PCDs gen erated redshift from 520 nm to 580 nm and from 575 nm to 630 nm. Comparing with OCDs, they concluded that a conjugate effect of quantumsize effect and higher nitrogen content could be partly responsible for the red emission of the PCDs.
With the assistance of acids, such as HNO3, H3PO4, HF, etc.,[59] RCDs were synthesized from pPD by He’s group and

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Naphthalene-Based CDs
sections.text: The structure of naphthalene is the smallest sp2 domain, which can act as a building block to form a largesized conju gated sp2 cluster. By using sodiumnaphthalene, Yu’s group procured Ndoped CDs with excitationindependent red emis sion at 588 nm in acetonitrile under roomtemperature.[61] The FL characteristics depend on the molecular state of Nbonded aromatic carbon rings in the CDs. Employing the control lable sequential dehydrative condensation and dehydrogena tive planarization (DCDSP) method, Yang’s group achieved highly efficient RCDs centered at 628 nm with a QY up to 53%.[62] Particularly, the RCDs were prepared by treating 1, 3dihydroxynaphthalene, containing the structure of naphtha lene, and KIO4 in ethanol solution followed by purification using silica gel column chromatography (Figure 6a). They demonstrated that RCDs consisted of uniformly large sized conjugated sp2 clusters, resulting in the strong red emission.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Polythiophene-Based CDs
sections.text:
Using conjugated polymer, polythiophene derivatives as the carbon source, highly waterdispersible CDs with a strong emis sion peaking at 680 nm was obtained by using a hydrothermal method.[63] Ge et al. produced novel CDs from polythiophene phenylpropionic acid (PPA) with a broad absorption band in the visible to NIR region and red emission (640 nm).[64] Poly thiophene 1 (PT1) with carboxyl groups and polythiophene 2 (PT2) with quaternary ammonium salts are considered as Odoped and Ndoped polythiophene derivatives, respectively. By changing the ratio of PT1 and PT2, Ge’s group further fabri cated multicolor emissive CDs ranging from blue to NIR under excitation of 400 nm (Figure 6b).[65] They inferred that both the tuneable absorption and FL mechanism of the CDs exhibited strong red shift with the increasing proportion of PT2 resulting from different surface states and N contents. In a study,[66] by using polythiophene benzoic acid as a carbon source, Wang’s group prepared CDs with bright fluorescence in the red region. The redshift in emission peak with increasing excitation wave lengths was primarily caused by different sizes and different emissive sites on CDs. By modification the surface of CDs, this group further designed an NIRlightresponsive and vein inject able CDs nanosphere (CDNS).[67] Compared with the individual CDs, the assembled CDNS exhibited a redshifted absorption and a broader absorption band from 400 to 800 nm.

sections.heading: 2.2.5. Amino Acid–Based CDs
sections.text:
Amino acids owning both amino and carboxyl group are compat ible in biological systems, which have been used as ideal initial reactants. In 2016, Lin’s group adopted microwaveassisted treat ment of glutathione (GSH) and formamide and first synthesized RCDs with an emission peak at 683 nm (Figure 6c).[70] They revealed that the emission of the NIRCDs was large as a result of the surface molecular state. Based on a single precursor of argi nine in pure water,[71] Chen et al. achieved the size and colortune able CDs (blue to red by simply varying concentration and reaction time). Interestingly, a reversible spectra shift of CDs was observed upon dilution, which was predominantly attributed to altered CDsCDs interparticle interaction, leading to minimum self absorption. By choosing the appropriate ratio of arginine, ethylen ediamine, naphthalene dianhydride, and 2, 6dibromonaphtalene dianhydride, Maurizio Prato’s group prepared pure whitelight emitting CDs covering a broad range from 400–700 nm.[72] Additionally, the predicted FL characteristics of these CDs in this region was representative of 2, 6naphthalene diimides substituted with one bromine and one amino substituent, leading to their absorption and fluorescence toward the red region.

sections.heading: 2.2.6. Saccharide-Based CDs
sections.text: Saccharides are inexpensive nontoxic chemicals such as sucrose, fructose, lactose and glucose, and have been adopted in laboratory with inexpensive equipment.[14,73] Gude et al. syn thesized orangered emitting CDs from saccharides such as sucrose, fructose and glucose in acidic medium.[74] These CDs showed an excitationindependent FL emission in the orange red region (maximum emission at 590 nm) (Figure 6d). They demonstrated that CDs possessed only one type of chromo phore, hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) derivative, as a major component, which caused a large Stokes shift (≈150 nm).

sections.heading: 2.2.7. Other Doped CDs
sections.text:
To prepare farred to NIR CDs, there are some other kinds of pre cursors like dyes,[75,76] natural products[77] and so on. For example, using hydrophobic cyanine dye and poly (ethylene glycol), NIR CDs with emission range from 600 to 900 nm was prepared via a simple solvothermal process.[75] By using manganese (II) phthalocyanine as a precursor, MnCDs with strongly NIR peak at 745 nm are also prepared.[76] Using pPD and isocyanatopro pyltriethoxysilane (IPTS) as precursors, Xie et al. prepared silane functionalized CDs with red emission (RSiCDs) under white light emitting diode.[78] The asfabricated RSiCDs was prepared from pPD and NaOH in ethanol via onestep solvothermal treat ment. RSiCDs emitted redshift light from 596 nm to 604 nm when excited from 500 to 560 nm with a QY of 99%.
Although remarkable progress in preparing versatile farred to NIR CDs has been made by different methods, such as selecting proper precursors and solvent, optimiz ing reaction time and temperature, etc., the luminescence mechanism of these CDs remains unproven. Such diverse reports ascribe to different explanations for the mechanism of CDs emitting farred to NIR. First, most literatures assert that by controlling surface state or defect[19,35,36,39,47,51,54,55,57,61,65,70]/functional groups[34,35,55,61]/ surface oxidation of CDs, the CDs with desired farred to NIR emitting properties can be consequently engineered. In 2017, Xiong’ group attested that the band gap strongly depending on the incorporated oxygen species was reduced as an increasing degree of surface oxidation. In addition, the larger the size of CDs, the more obviously the emission of CDs redshift because of the quantum size effect and the narrowing bandgap between highest occupied molecular orbital and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital.[18,50,66] It has also been reported that the het eroatom doping such as F,[48] N,[53] S,[57] etc., favors the redshift of carbon emission, and the higher content of N[50,65] and O,[30] the larger redshift. Moreover, the synergistic effect of the carbon coregraphitic N and the surface state CO play important roles in the red emission. Such debate is probably derived from the different precursors and synthetic procedures in the formation of the CDs. Moreover, a carbogenic core with a large sp2 domain also plays a crucial role in farred to NIR emitting luminescent center of carbon dots.[51,62] For instance, by using CA and dopa mine as a carbon source, Yang′ group explored the exact mecha nism of farred to NIR emission CDs. They declared that farred to NIR luminescent evidently due to the synergistic effect of the carbon core and the surface state. In another report, a single
type of aggregated chromophoric (HMF derivative) structure was proved to be the fluorescing unit.[74] Despite these reported developments, it is exigent to develop controlled ways to prepare farred to NIR emission CDs and welldefined mole cular origin of their luminescent.

sections.heading: 3. Applications in Biosensing, Bioimaging, and Therapy
sections.text: With their unique properties, such as easy preparation and functionalization, small size, excellent biocompatibility and chemical inertness, CDs have been used in various fields, such as sensing,[79,80] bioimaging,[81] nanomedicine, photo catalysis and electrocatalysis, etc. Notably, compared with most green and yellow CDs, farred to NIR CDs have many advantages, such as deep tissue penetration, low interferences from autofluorescence and minimal photodamage to biolog ical samples. To boost these applications of CDs, extensive research efforts have been devoted. As a consequence, the applications of farred to NIR CDs in biomedical fields, including biosensing, bioimaging, and therapy, have been developed in recent years.

sections.heading: 3.1. Biosensing
sections.text: As versatile fluorescent nanomaterials, farred to NIR CDs were employed as various sensors in vitro or in vivo because of their obvious merits, like small size, flexible surface modification, excellent chemical stability, etc. Recently, this diverse farred to NIR CDsbased system has been used for the measuring of dis tinctive metal ions, small biomolecules, gaseous molecules and even fingerprints.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Detection of Metal Ions
sections.text:
Using farred to NIR CDs, various metal ions, such as Fe3+, Cu2+, Ag+, etc., have been detected through the signal change in fluorescence intensity resulting from the surface bonding of CDs with metal ions.[82] Lin’s group proposed colortune able Ndoped RCDs for Fe3+ detection.[56] In their study, these CDs were sensitive to Fe3+ in aqueous and living cells, which were realized via the red emission fluorescent quenching. After the addition of Fe3+, the average FL lifetime of the CDs was changed from 6.7 to 2.8 ns. The result suggested that the dynamics quenching occurred between Fe3+ and the surface functional groups of CDs, arising from the formation of a stable nonfluorescence complex. They proposed that the pres ence of amino groups on the CDs surface was responsible for the performance of Fe3+ sensing. Moreover, the CDs were also successfully applied for detecting intracellular Fe3+ with very weak red fluorescence emission observed. That is to say, N doped CDs can be served as an effective probe for Fe3+ sensing.
Then, Miao et al. also synthesized Fe3+ sensitive red emis sive S, Ndoped CDs from CA and thiourea in the solution of acetone.[45] Chen’s group designed a colorimetric and red emis sionfluorescent nanosensor for Fe3+ based on B, N, Scodoped

CDs (Figure 7a).[57] These work suggested that the presence of functional groups on the surface of the CDs endowed the carbon dots with high sensitivity for the detection of Fe3+.
There are also other metal ion sensors based on farred to NIR emission CDs including Cu2+[40] and Ag+.[48] Similar to the sensing mechanism of Fe3+, most strategies are based on the quenching fluorescence of CDs by metal ions. For instance, Chen et al. fabricated Cu2+ sensing multicolor CDs by using CA/urea as carbon and nitrogen sources and DMF as a sol vent.[40] The multicolor CDs solution detected Cu2+ through red fluorescence quenching process, which was reversible after introducing strong Cu2+ chelator ethylenediaminetet raacetic acid (EDTA) and can be carried out for several times without significant fluorescence decrease. The strong interac tions between Cu2+ and the N functional groups were believed to contribute to the ultrasensitive Cu2+ sensing. Using 1, 2diamino4, 5difluorobenzene as precursor and tartaric acid as solvent, Zuo et al. reported a Fdoped CDs based sensor to detect Ag+.[48] Ag+ can selectively bind to functional groups on the surfaces of Fdoped CDs. Therefore, the Fdoped CDs can be used as a highly sensitive sensor for Ag+ in aqueous solution and cell system.
Another appealing and accurate strategy for simultaneously detecting diverse metal ions is multidimensional sensing.[83] in which using fullcolor CDs was reported as a feasible option
by Pan et al.[34] Based on CDs, Pan et al. have prepared a fullcolor CDs to detect diverse metal ions. The CDs can be quenched by a variety of metal ions with different efficien cies. Based on this, a multidimensional sensing platform for different metal ions was designed by facilely changing the excitation wavelengths.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Detection of Small Molecules
sections.text: During the development of sensing metal ions, farred to NIR emitting CDs have made much progress in the detection of small molecules.[60] For example, tuneable multicolor water soluble CDs were designed by Tripathi and colleagues using globally generated pollutant carbon soot.[20] The CDs could be easily conjugated with biological species like peptide due to the presence of carboxylate on their surface. Therefore, a sensor for cholesterol based on the ionpair conjugation of CDsmethylene blue was described.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Detection of Biomarkers
sections.text:
In addition to metal ions and small molecules, farred to NIR emitting CDs also have many applications in detecting

In 2015, based on RCDs, Lin’s group prepared an onoffon fluores cent probe for detecting glutathione (GSH) and tempera ture.[53] As shown in Figure 7b, the fluorescence of CDs was quenched due to the interaction between the surface group and GSH, however, with increasing temperature, the interac tion was destroyed and the fluorescence recovered gradually. Moreover, the RCDs were also used to monitor the change of temperature and its gradient in MC3T3E1 cells. Xiong’s group synthesized the bright to detect latent fingerprint. The RCDs can be put on many solid surfaces and show an obvious latent fingerprint (LFP) under UV light.[55] The LFPs stained by the RCDs could remain red fluorescence in the air for a long time. The coffeering effect during water evaporation and the electrostatic interactions between RCDs and the finger print residues prevented the red fluorescence at the fingerprint edges from quenching. Up to now, various biosensors based on diverse farred to NIR fluorescence CDs from different precursors and strate gies have been developed, and these works have been summa rized in Table 1. Such variations reported to be very crucial and decisive, because the fluorescence characteristics are mainly dependent on the constitution and the surface chemical groups of the farred to NIR emission CDs, which was inevitably resulted from the specific precursors and synthetic routes. Con sequently, the standard strategies for producing farred to NIR CDs and valid analysis for the properties of farred to NIR CDs are in imperative need.

sections.heading: 3.2. Bioimaging
sections.text: In recent times, there has increasing interest in the devel opment of excellent fluorescent CDs as contrast agents for imaging in vivo.[50] Ideally, fluorescent probes for in vivo imaging should possess high QY, NIR excitation and NIR emission, minimum toxicity and photodamage to biological samples. The rationale for the use of inherent farred to NIR emitting CDs in visualizing biological systems both in vitro and in vivo is now a challenging topic.[70]

sections.heading: 3.2.1. One-Photon Fluorescence Bioimaging
sections.text:
Since the onephoton fluorescence bioimaging application of CDs was first reported by Sun et al.,[45] RCDs for in vivo and in vitro bioimaging have been reported successively. For example, Lin’s group designed excitationdependent multi color CDs for cell imaging (Figure 8a). And Xiong’s group reported fullcolor CDs for cell imaging under a single excita tion wavelength (405 nm).[54] In another research, Guo et al. reported multicolor CDs with tuneable emissions ranging from blue to NIR (680 nm) under a single wavelength of 400 nm for cell imaging.[65]
Besides in vitro cell imaging, RCDs was also used for in vivo imaging.[84] The viability of CDs as red fluorescent contrast agents in live mice was first verified by Yang’s group. In their experiment, after subcutaneous injection, significant red fluo rescence of the CDs could be observed in mice. These results demonstrated that CDs could perform as an excellent agent for in vivo bioimaging with low cytotoxicity and good pen etrability.[61] In addition to singlephoton imaging application, twophoton (TP) fluorescence imaging and photoacoustic (PA) imaging[64,84] also have been used for bioimaging with great spatial resolution and deep tissues as well.
Fluorescent nanomaterial with both excitation and emis sion in the farred and NIR region are highly appealing in the area of bioimaging. Using a PVP functionalized CDs, Rogach’s group performed NIR fluorescence imaging in vivo. As shown in Figure 8b, after a gavage injection of CDs/PVP aqueous solu tion, an obvious red fluorescence was observed in the stomach of the mouse (right one) under 671 nm laser excitation.[44]

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Two-Photon Fluorescence Bioimaging
sections.text: TP imaging technique, which employ NIR light as the excita tion source, possesses various benefits, such as, large penetra tion depth, minimal photodamage and long observation time. Lin’s group reported NIR emissive CDs (λmax = 683 nm)[70] and pure red emissive (λmax ≈ 640 nm) CDs.[35] The NIR CDs have a series of features including good water dispersibility, low cyto toxicity, and high QY.[35] More interestingly, the NIR CDs were verified to be capable of twophoton fluorescence bioimaging in deep tissue. As seen in twophoton mode, deepred emis sion from the MCF7 cells can be observed under the confocal imaging technique (Figure 9a), clearly indicating the abilities of the NIRCDs as twophoton bioimaging agents. While the RCDs have a higher QY of 22.9% as well as excellent counter stain compatibilities of nucleolus both in onephoton and two photon modes. The localization of the RCDs in nucleolus was demonstrated by ribonuclease digestion study,[85] and the accu mulation process was contributed to the stronger emission.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Photoacoustic Bioimaging
sections.text:
CDs are still as a great candidate for in vivo fluorescence tracking agent,[86] because they can avoid the interference of autofluorescence background (green).[87] RCDs for fluorescence imaging and PA imaging under the NIR excitation (671 nm) in living mice were revealed by Ge’s group. The CDs have a broad emission from 500 to 800 nm with a peak at 640 nm. Utilizing the dually emitting CDs, successful attempts were made as a useful contrast agent in NIR lighttriggered FL imaging and PA imaging in mice tumors (Figure 9b).[64] After injection, the CDs accumulate in the HeLa tumor area through the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect. Significant FL and PA images at different time points were observed in the tumor area in comparison with other tissues. Meanwhile, obvious PA signals was maintained after prolonged circulation in blood ves sels during the imaging process. These results demonstrated that the redCDs can simultaneously act as FL and PA image agent for in vivo imaging.[84]

In future, CDs with longer wavelength excitation and emis sion, especially in the region of NIRII for deeper penetration and higher resolution of specific organelles or organs, may be achieved by carefully selecting proper precursors and methods of synthesis.

sections.heading: 3.3. Cancer Therapy Based on Far-Red and NIR CDs
sections.text: Effective early diagnosis and therapy methods are becoming more and more desirable in the prevention and treatment of cancer, especially photoactivated theragnostic. NIR light triggered therapeutic methods, such as photothermal therapy (PTT), photodynamic therapy (PDT), and chemotherapy, have been actively used owing to relatively low autofluores cence of tissues and mediums in the transparency window (650–950 nm).[88] Farred to NIR emission CDs are very appealing as neonatal theragnostic agents.

sections.heading: 3.4. Photothermal Therapy
sections.text:
Recently, PTT agents based on longwavelength light in the region of red, NIR and even the TP excitation activated CDs were successively designed. Ge and colleagues first con structed RCDs (640 nm) as multimodal FL, PA diagnosis and photothermal therapy (PTT). The RCDs, which possess a high photothermal conversion efficiency of 38.5%, have been used for PTT in live mice under NIR irradiation (671 nm).[64] The IR thermographic results of mice revealed that the local tumor temperature could rise to 58.4 °C after incubated with RCDs under NIR laser excitation. Other RCDs, which possess high photothermal conversion efficiency of 43.9% also showed great potential for PTT (Figure 10a).[35] The RCDs have unique NIR absorption feature (650–800 nm) and special nucleolus locali zation ability. Compared with the temperatures of pure water and medium for cell cultivation with the only increase of 1.3 and 1.4 °C, the temperature of the RCDs solution increased by 19.5–60.4 °C. Upon laser irradiation for as short as 6 min, nearly all of the MCF7 cells were killed when the concentration of the RCDs increased to 200 µg mL−1.
Excitingly, the CDs with strong absorption and NIR emission range from 600 to 900 nm show great potential for PTT in vitro and in vivo. For example, the CDs from hydrophobic cyanine dye own preferential uptake at tumors and high photothermal conversion efficiency under irradiation with an 808 nm NIR laser.[75] Zhang’s group reported that S, Secodoped CDs from PT2 and diphenyl diselenide exhibited a photothermal conver sion efficiency of ≈58.2% through the TP excitation contribute to the large twophoton absorption crosssection.[68]

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Photodynamic Therapy
sections.text: According to recent studies about their fancy ability to efficiently generate singlet oxygen (1O2), CDs are promising nanomedi cine in the biomedical field. Up to now, polythiophene has been selected as a nonexpendable precursor to prepare farred to NIR CDs as a PDT reagent.[63,67] Han’s group presented a PDT agent producing with a 1O2 quantum yield of 1.3% based on CDs using PT2.[63] Wang et al. further obtained better CDs with higher 1O2 QY of 45% under longer excited laser irradiation of 671 nm.[67] In addition, these CDs were successfully utilized as NIRtrig gered simultaneous FL imaging and PDT agent with low long term toxicity. Using hydrophobic cyanine dye and poly (ethylene glycol), and Zheng’s group also demonstrated the capability of CDs for PDT.[75] However, to overcome hypoxia resulting from the rapid consumption of oxygen in the PDT process, Wang’s group develop a novel magnetofluorescent MnCDs as an in situ tumor oxygenator which was prepared by the precursors of man ganese (II) phthalocyanine and then selfassembly cooperated with DSPEPEG (Figure 10b). The obtained MnCDs possesses lots of merits such as good physiological stability, NIR fluores cence (maximum peak at 745 nm) and T1weighted magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, as well as efficient 1O2 generation (QY: 0.40%). Importantly, because the MnCDs could catalyze H2O2 to generate oxygen, tumor hypoxia was improved and the enhanced PDT was consequently realized.[76]

sections.text:
Recently, nanomaterialbased immunotherapy has become an effective strategy for cancer therapy. Besides liposomes,

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Synergistic Therapy
sections.text:
Nowadays, the new synergistic treatment assays for cancer therapy, particularly NIR lighttriggered simultaneous PTT and PDT therapies, provide the hope to enhance the anticancer efficacy of single PTT or PDT. Wang et al. demonstrated that multimodal CDs can be used as redexcited cancer theragnostic for simultaneous imagingbased PDT and PTT.[66] The reported CDs exhibited dual PDT and PTT functions under the 635 nm laser irradiation with singlet oxygen (1O2) generating efficiency of 27% and high photothermal conversion efficiency of 36.2%. Lin’s group also validated the project that loading a small amount of photosensitizers onto a PTT agent to overcome the shortcomings of PTT and PDT. They loaded photosensitizer chlorin e6 (Ce6) (0.56% of mass) onto aminorich RCDs that possess superior photothermal character under 671 nm NIR laser.[37] These works indicated that CDs as a neonatal red or

sections.heading: 4. The Development of Far-Red to NIR CDs in Future
sections.text:
Despite the numerous merits of most green and yellow CDs, such as great biocompatibility, good water solubility, excellent photostability, farred and NIR CDs have more advantages including strong tissue penetration depth, less light damage, minimum interference from autofluorescence and thus have been employed in various applications in biomedical fields over the past decades. At present, literature reports that CDs with both farred to NIR light excitation and emission have been obtained through the concerted selection of suitable pre cursors in special solutions, particular synthesis methods and appropriate purification methods. Moreover, multicolor CDs with different FL properties were separated depending on size or charge. Such diverse CDs have been used for biosensing, bioimaging, and cancer therapy.
Despite such remarkable progress in syntheses of farred to NIR and application in biosensing and cancer therapy, there remain several challenges preventing their practical applica tions. First, the controllable synthesis of both farred and NIR and even the NIRII (900–1500 nm) light excited and emissive CDs are yet to be known, which may be realized by choosing proper precursors and synthetic methods. In addition, recent reports posit that the main luminescence mechanism of these long wavelengthCDs is as a result of the surface states and the doping with N as well as other elements. However, these explanations are not comprehensive enough. Therefore, it is imperative that researchers study in detail the luminescence mechanism of these CDs by carefully investigating both the chemical structure and size of these NIR CDs.
Second, these NIR CDs showed low QY in aqueous solution thus greatly limiting their in vivo application. Therefore, an innovation of synthetic method for the preparation of CDs with more desired performance in biological applications urgently demands attention and action. Moreover, the application of far red and NIR CDs in biosensing, diagnosis, drugloading and other important activities require tedious surface functional ized. In this case, more efforts should be made on developing single CDs with excellent biocompatibility and good stability in a complex biological environment.
Third, most of the reported CDs with single FL, FL/TP, or FL/ PA imaging possess intrinsic drawbacks such as low resolution and poor sensitivity, thus multimodal imaging techniques based on farred and NIR CDs are a huge challenge and needed to under stand the indepth in vivo behavior, including specific metabolism and inter/intracellular functions in organisms. Moreover, there exist various biological barriers, immune response and short cir culation time during the delivery of CDs. So, greater work should be put on designing more biocompatible CDs to overcome these problems and explore their clinical applications.
With such efforts, we expected that the study of farred and NIR CDs will open new perspectives toward the designing and synthesis of CDs that meets the requirement of diagnosis and therapy.

referenceMentions.context: [14] To date, multitudinous precursors from natural materials to laboratory­produced chemicals have been used to prepare CDs through hydrothermal,[6,23–25] and microwave[26] assisted approaches.

Otyepka’s group proposed a comparative computational study of CDs models CA and EDA and they revealed that red shift of CDs due to electron doping effect, other than pyri­ dinic, pyrrolic, or amino centers.[31] In 2015, Rogach’s group reported excitation­dependent CDs by using anhydrous CA and N­(b­aminoethyl)­g­aminopropylmethyldimethoxysilane (AEAPMS).
